title: Moxie Cinema: Two years strong today
body: Two years ago today, on September 21, 2005, The Moxie officially opened its doors to the public after nearly a year's worth of start-up delays. Now, two year's on, I find myself sitting in the waiting room of St. John's urgent care center, painstakingly typing this blog post into my new web-enabled phone with what seems to be the world's smallest keypad. I suppose that's the price you pay for new technology. EDIT: Now I'm in the patient room, waiting for the doctor. I'm here to get an allergy shot (hopefully), although they just informed me that my blood pressure was alarmingly high (145/93). I don't know... probably a side effect from one of the five over-the-counter allergy medicines coursing through my veins. Now they have me worried though... damn nurses and their paranoia-inducing bedside manner. I hear them laughing outside the door -- probably joking about how my heart is going to explode any minute now. It's getting increasingly difficult to type as my hands are becoming more and more sweaty. Now, where was I? Ah yes, ye olde Moxie and the momentous day. We went all out last year, with a week's worth of activities to celebrate our big one year. The reason being the fact that the majority of small businesses fail within their first 12 months, so we felt we owed it to ourselves, and our supportive customers, to mark the occasion appropriately. That last sentence sounds terribly labored, but it's too hard to erase it all on this little keypad! EDIT: Doctor says my high blood pressure was caused by all the Sudafed I took today. No worries... and no allergy shot either. :( I did, however, get some Allegra and steroid nasal spray. Hopefully it will start working soon. So, the second year is important as well, but we didn't feel any real pressing need to celebrate as lavishly as last year. We did, however, offer $0.50 popcorn to everyone on our e-mail list, so that's something. I like that... saying "however" all the time... it's something I do a lot when I talk too.... but that's neither here nor there... and I'm getting off topic. After having successfully weathered out another year of working seven days a week, and spending nearly every waking hour with each other, which isn't as easy or pleasant as it may seem, Nicole and I are taking a mini-vacation starting tomorrow. We'll be heading up to St. Louis for a day (Nic's in a crafts show, and we'll be visiting and staying with friends), and then on Sunday we'll be flying to the BIG APPLE (our first time) to see a Bjork concert on Monday night! Also, while we're in New York, we're going to meet with several of our distributors who have offices in Manhattan (Fox, Sony, Magnolia, etc.). So it's half business / half fun -- although the fun will outweigh the business... as it should. It's a much-needed break, and the sole reason I went to the urgent care center tonight. No one wants to have an allergy attack during their first trip to the big city. And that's it. I have a lot of stuff that I need to get ready for our fateful employees, who will be captaining the USS Moxie while we're on shore-leave, so I best get to work. If you guys have any tips on where we should go while we're in NYC, feel free to leave them in the comments. Thanks for a great two years, and we look forward to bringing you many more fantastic cinematic experiences in the years to come.

comments.author: PullTheString
comments.body:
Congrats Dan & Nicole!

Two New York suggestions:

Yankee Stadium -- I know quite well your affinity lies with a different team, but the atmosphere on game night is unmatched in the Midwest (we think we know what it means to be a rabid fan until we visit an East Coast team).

And after all the jeers of my fellow posters (c'mon... the Yankees! That's like cheering for Microsoft), more realistically...

Les Paul plays every Monday night at the Iridium Jazz Club... the man in person for a rather lengthy show.

Have fun... you deserve it.

M

PS My grandpa was a Yankee scout, so the pinstripes were bred into me early....

oh! and go eat at the Zen Palate in Union Square! it's my favorite restaurant in the city, hands-down. all vegetarian, it will blow your freaking mind.

also the Strand bookstore on Broadway and 12th. biggest and bestest bookstore known to man..

i probably have a million other things too..just can't think of stuff...

if you're looking for a bar, go the lower east side, walk down avenue a and prepare for crazyness...

comments.author: dan
comments.body: Gosh. We did a lot... Sunday: Hotel in Chelsea Ate at a Thai place called Spice on 8th and 20th Ground Zero Battery Park (looked at the Statue of Liberty from afar) Tribeca Film Festival Shorts Film Celebration (didn't stay to watch a film though) Wall Street, and the financial district SoHo Shake Shack Angelika to see TAoJJBtCRF Monday: Dunkin Donuts The Dakota Strawberry Fields Central Park Park Avenue Times Square (yuck!) Shake Shack Bjork @ MSG Tuesday: Train to Brooklyn Walked back to the city across the Brooklyn Bridge Rockefeller Plaza Lunch at Cosi's NBC Experience store Visited Fox's film offices Visited Magnolia's film offices Visited ThinkFilm's offices Cab ride from Chelsea to LaGuardia at 5:00 pm via the Tri-Burrough, since the midtown was jammed *phew* And that's it. We also went to the City Museum on Saturday night, but that was in St. Louis, not NYC. It was a blast. Not nearly as dirty, scary, or pretentious as I thought it would be.

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Distribution companies have a department called "acquisitions," and the sole purpose of said department is to watch every movie they can get their hands on, and help the company decide which ones are worth buying. A typical person who works in acquisitions can watch upwards of 25 movies per week.

RJ, your goal in life should be to become an acquisitions employee. Granted, you might have to cut back on your typical weekly movie intake, but I think you might enjoy it. I hear they fast forward through most of them too... so you've got that going for you as well.
